html:
AI replacement and people displacement

What NAFTA can teach us about AI and power inequality

In a recent innovation conference, Gary Vaynerchuk, one of the keynote speakers, addressed AI as a tsunami heading our way.

“Technology is like a humongous wave. … 98% of this room is gonna put their head in the sand on AI and the wave is gonna crush them.” — Gary Vaynerchuk. Link to a similar speech

Conferences are often marred by predictions that never materialize, but what really stuck with me is the fear in the eyes of some audience members.

Those glances with a hint of terror seemed familiar. Like a long-forgotten memory of a tsunami I witnessed many years ago.

Fear is impossible to wipe clean.

In 1994, I was a teenager with a teenager's brain, feeling forced by my parents to spend my Saturday mornings at an English academy.

Secretly, my rebellion was never about giving me opportunity to learn the language of MTV; it was about spending part of my weekend trying to speak English with a group of older male professionals, when I could have invested that time in a newly discovered imperative: Trying to talk to Spanish with girls my age (something I never mastered in either language).
